JavaScript

The Basics

First and foremost, we make an attempt to adhere to the WordPress JS coding standards.

Code style

All javascript should be well documented. Functions, namespaces should adhere to the jsdoc 3 standard, available here: [[http://usejsdoc.org/about-getting-started.html]].

Inside functions declare additional comments with the // syntax.

Variable declaration

Variable declarations should be comma separated:

var v, x, y;

var $this = $(this),
    $that = $(that),
    i = 0;

NOTE: Watch for implicit globals when declaring your variables. This is a very common issue, especially with iterators in javascript loops. Leaking these to global scope can yield unexpected results.

Utility functions, state, tests and options for the main plugins should be stored in tribe-events.js and tribe-events-pro.js.

If functions or portions of functionality move between plugins, make sure all associated js code moves to that new area with them.

Event namespacing

To promote flexible event handling within jQuery, namespacing events is preferred over prefixing custom event names.

Why?

Namespacing allows a developer to add and remove events in an isolated fashion. CSS-Tricks has an excellent write-up about why they are awesome.

Namespacing conventions

Namespaced custom events should use the following convention:

[event name].tribe

[event name]

The [event name] should be something that indicates the action that is occurring. If saving a ticket, an event name of save-ticket would be appropriate - fry-bacon would not.

tribe

This is the piece of the namespace that should be present everywhere. It separates our events from those of other plugins.
